snomtools.data.datasets module¶

This file contains the base class for datasets.

class snomtools.data.datasets.Axis(data, unit=None, label=None, plotlabel=None, h5target=None)[source]¶

Bases: snomtools.data.datasets.DataArray

An axis is a data array that holds the data for an axis of a dataset.

__getattr__(item)[source]¶

This method provides dynamical naming in instances. It is called any time an attribute of the intstance is not found with the normal naming mechanism. Raises an AttributeError if the name cannot be resolved.

Parameters:item – The name to get the corresponding attribute.
Returns:The attribute corresponding to the given name.
__init__(data, unit=None, label=None, plotlabel=None, h5target=None)[source]¶

So far, an Axis is the same as a DaraArray, with the exception that it is one-dimensional. Therefore this method uses the __init__ of the parent class and parameters are exactly as there.

Parameters:
  • data –
  • unit –
  • label –
  • plotlabel –
Returns:

assure_1D()[source]¶

Makes sure the data is onedimensional. Try a consistent conversion, if that fails raise error.

classmethod from_dataarray(da)[source]¶

Initializes an Axis instance from a DataArray instance (which is mostly, but not completely the same).

Parameters:da – An instance of the DataArray class.
Returns:The new initialized instance of Axis.
get_index_searchsort(values)[source]¶

Assuming the axis elements are sorted (which should be the case, the way all is implemented atm), for every value given, there is a corresponding index in the array, where the value could be inserted while maintaining order of the array. This function searches these indexes by using the numpy.searchsorted function.

Parameters:values – array_like: Values to insert into the axis.
Returns:array of ints: The corresponding indexes with the same shape as values.
scale_linear(scaling=1.0, offset=None, unit=None, label=None, plotlabel=None)[source]¶

Transforms the Axis by scaling it with a linear factor and optionally shifting it by an offset. :param scaling: The scaling factor. :param offset: The offset. Must have the same dimension as the scaled axis. :param unit: Specifies the output unit for the Axis, Must evaluate a unit with same dimension as the scaled axis. :return: The transformed Axis.

__getitem__(key)[source]¶

To allow adressing parts or elements of the DataArray with [], including slicing as in numpy. This just forwards to the underlying __getitem__ method of the data object.

Parameters:key – The key which is given as adressed in dataarray[key]. Can be an integer or a slice object.
Returns:The sliced data as returned by self.data[key].
__init__(data, unit=None, label=None, plotlabel=None, h5target=None, chunks=True, compression='gzip', compression_opts=4, chunk_cache_mem_size=None)[source]¶

Guess what, this is an initializer. It differences between input formats, which should be clear from the parameter doc and the comments in the code.

Parameters:
  • data – required. If this is already a DataArray instance, it is just copied by default, so if the other parameters are set, the contents of the instance are overwritten.
  • unit – Request a unit for the data to be in. If the data holds a unit (quantity), it must be the same dimensionality. If it doesn’t (array-like), it is assumed to be in the given unit! Default is None for unchanged in the first case and dimensionless in the second.
  • label – A short identifier label that should be meaningful to get the physical context of the data.
  • plotlabel – A label for the data that should be plotted in a diagram.
Returns:

Flushes HDF5 buffers to disk. This only makes sense in h5 disk mode and in non-tempfile mode.

  • h5target – Optional. The HDF5 target to work on, if on-disk h5 mode is desired.

Parameters:h5source – The HDF5 source to read from. This is generally the subgroup for the DataArray.
Returns:The initialized DataArray.

Projects the datafield onto the given axes. Uses sum() method, but adresses axes to keep instead of axes to sum over.

Parameters:args – Integer indices for the axes to project onto.
Returns:ndarray quantity: The projected data.

shape[source]¶
shift(shift, output=None, order=0, mode='constant', cval=nan, prefilter=None)[source]¶
Shifts the complete data. This is just calling the underlying methods implemented in
Data_Handler_H5.shift() and Data_Handler_np.shift() See those methods for documentation or under-the-hood-used scipy.ndimage.interpolation.shift() for full documentation of parameters.
shift_slice(slice_, shift, output=None, order=0, mode='constant', cval=nan, prefilter=None)[source]¶
Shifts a certain slice of the data. This is just calling the underlying methods implemented in
Data_Handler_H5.shift_slice() and Data_Handler_np.shift_slice() See those methods for documentation or under-the-hood-used scipy.ndimage.interpolation.shift() for full documentation of parameters.
classmethod stack(datastack, axis=0, unit=None, label=None, plotlabel=None, h5target=None)[source]¶

Stacks a sequence of DataArrays to a new DataArray. See numpy.stack, as this method is used.

Parameters:
  • datastack – sequence of DataArrays: The Data to be stacked.
  • axis – int, optional: The axis in the result array along which the input arrays are stacked.
  • unit – string, optional: The unit for the stacked DataArray. All data must be convertible to that unit. If not given, the unit of the first DataArray in the input stack is used.
  • label – string, optional: The label for the new DataSet. If not given, the label of the first DataArray in the input stack is used.
  • plotlabel – string, optional: The plotlabel for the new DataArray. If not given, the label of the first DataArray in the input stack is used.
Returns:

The stacked DataArray.
store_to_h5(h5dest, subgrp_name=None, chunks=True, compression='gzip', compression_opts=4)[source]¶

Stores the DataArray into a HDF5 file. It will create a new subgroup and store the data there in a unified format.

Parameters:
  • h5dest – The destination. This is a HDF5 file or subgroup.
  • subgrp_name – Optional. The name for the subgroup that is created to store the data in, Default is the label of the DataArray.

:return The subgroup that was created and holds the data.

sum(axis=None, dtype=None, out=None, keepdims=False)[source]¶

Behaves as the sum() function of a numpy array. See: http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.10.1/reference/generated/numpy.sum.html

Parameters:
  • axis – None or int or tuple of ints, optional Axis or axes along which a sum is performed. The default (axis = None) is perform a sum over all the dimensions of the input array. axis may be negative, in which case it counts from the last to the first axis. New in version 1.7.0.: If this is a tuple of ints, a sum is performed on multiple axes, instead of a single axis or all the axes as before.
  • dtype – dtype, optional The type of the returned array and of the accumulator in which the elements are summed. By default, the dtype of a is used. An exception is when a has an integer type with less precision than the default platform integer. In that case, the default platform integer is used instead.
  • out – ndarray, optional Array into which the output is placed. By default, a new array is created. If out is given, it must be of the appropriate shape (the shape of a with axis removed, i.e., numpy.delete(a.shape, axis)). Its type is preserved. See doc.ufuncs (Section Output arguments) for more details.
  • keepdims – bool, optional If this is set to True, the axes which are reduced are left in the result as dimensions with size one. With this option, the result will broadcast correctly against the original arr.
Returns:

ndarray Quantity An array with the same shape as a, with the specified axis removed. If a is a 0-d array, or if axis is None, a scalar is returned. If an output array is specified, a reference to out is returned.
sum_raw(axis=None, dtype=None, out=None, keepdims=False)[source]¶

As sum(), only on bare numpy array instead of Quantity. See sum() for details. :return: ndarray An array with the same shape as a, with the specified axes removed. If a is a 0-d array, or if axis is None, a scalar is returned. If an output array is specified, a reference to out is returned.

swapaxes(axis1, axis2)[source]¶

Swaps two axes of the data. Uses numpy.swapaxes.

Parameters:
  • axis1 – int: First axis.
  • axis2 – int: Second axis.
Returns:

The data after the transformation.
to(unitstr)[source]¶

Returns a copy of the dataarray with the unit set as specified. For compatibility with pint quantity. Warning: The plotlabel typically includes a unit, so this might get invalid!

Parameters:unitstr – A valid unit string.
Returns:The dataset copy with the specified unit.
units[source]¶
write_to_h5(h5dest=None, chunks=True, compression='gzip', compression_opts=4)[source]¶

Writes the DataArray into a HDF5 group. It will store the data there in a unified format. It will overwrite any dataset in the given group that is named with any of the unified names.

Parameters:h5dest – The destination. This is a HDF5 file or subgroup. Can be None if the DataSet has a h5target ( works on a h5 group in file mode), in that case, self.h5target will be taken.

:return The h5 group (or file) that holds the written data.

class snomtools.data.datasets.DataSet(label='', datafields=(), axes=(), plotconf=(), h5target=None, chunk_cache_mem_size=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A data set is a collection of data arrays combined to have a physical meaning. These are n-dimensional sets of physical values, in which every dimension itself has a physical meaning. This might for example be a 3D-array of count rates, in which the x- y- and z-dimensions represent the position on a sample (x, y in micrometers) and a time delay (z = t in femtoseconds).

check_label_uniqueness(newlabel=None)[source]¶

Checks if the labels of the DataSets datafields and axes are unique. This is important to call them directly by their labels.

Parameters:newlabel – If given, this method checks the viability of a new label to add to the DataSet.

classmethod from_h5(h5source, h5target=None, chunk_cache_mem_size=None)[source]¶

Initializes a new DataSet from an existing HDF5 source. The file must be structured in accordance to the saveh5() and loadh5() methods in this class. Uses loadh5 under the hood!

Parameters:h5source – The (absolute or relative) path of the HDF5 file to read, or an existing h5py Group/File of the base of the Dataset.
Returns:The initialized DataSet
classmethod from_h5file(path, h5target=None, chunk_cache_mem_size=None)[source]¶

Initializes a new DataSet from an existing HDF5 file. The file must be structured in accordance to the saveh5() and loadh5() methods in this class. Uses loadh5 under the hood! This method is kept for backwards compatibility, while newer from_h5 method expands its function.

Parameters:path – The (absolute or relative) path of the HDF5 file to read.
Returns:The initialized DataSet
classmethod from_textfile(path, h5target=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Initializes a new DataSet from an existing text file. The file must contain the data in a column structure and can contain additional metadata in comment lines. Uses load_textfile() under the hood! See doc of this method for more details!

Parameters:
  • path – The (absolute or relative) path of the text file to read.
  • kwargs – Keyword arguments for load_textfile and the underlying numpy.loadtxt(). See there documentation for specifics,
Returns:

The initialized DataSet

get_datafield_index(label_or_index)[source]¶
get_datafield_normalized(label_or_index, method='maximum')[source]¶

Like get_datafield, but returns a normalized DataArray.

Parameters:
  • label_or_index – Identifier of the DataField
  • method – Method to normalize with: Valid options: * “maximum”, “max” (default): divide every value by the maximum value in the set * “mean”: divide every value by the average value in the set * “minimum”, “min”: divide every value by the minimum value in the set * “absolute maximum”, “absmax”: divide every value by the maximum absolute value in the set * “absolute minimum”, “absmin”: divide every value by the minimum absolute value in the set
Returns:

The normalized DataArray instance.

classmethod in_h5(h5group)[source]¶
Opens a DataSet from a h5 source, which then works on the source (in-place). This is forwards to
from_h5(h5group, h5group).
Parameters:h5group – The (absolute or relative) path of the HDF5 file to read, or an existing h5py Group/File of the base of the Dataset.
Returns:The generated instance.
load_textfile(path, axis=0, comments='#', delimiter=None, unitsplitter='[-\/ ]+', labelline=0, unitsline=0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Loads the contents of a textfile to the dataset instance. The text files are two-dimensional arrays of lines and n columns, so it can hold up to one axis and (n-1) or n DataFields. See axis parameter for information on how to set axis. Data consistency is checked at the end, so shapes of data and axis arrays must fit (as always), Uses numpy.loadtxt() under the hood! Defaults fit for gnuplot friendly files. Tries to cast the heading comment line(s) as labels and units for the data fields.

Parameters:
  • path – The (relative or absolute) path of the text file to read.
  • axis – Integer that specifies the column of the axis in the data file OR a whole axis instance of the correct shape OR None for unchanged axes of the DataSet. Default is 0 for the first column of the text file.
  • comments – the character used to indicate the start of a comment line
  • delimiter – character used to separate values. By default, this is any whitespace.
  • unitsplitter – Regular expression to split comment columns in labels and units. Default is “[-/ ]+”, which matches combinations of the chars ‘-‘. ‘/’ and ‘ ‘.
  • labelline – Index (starting with 0) of the comment line in which the labels are stored. (Default 0)
  • unitsline – Index (starting with 0) of the comment line in which the units are stored. (Default 0) If this is different from labelline, it is assumed that ONLY the unit is in that line.
  • kwargs – Keyword arguments as used for the numpy.loadtxt() method
Returns:

Nothing
loadh5(h5source)[source]¶
meshgrid(axes=None)[source]¶

This function returns coordinate arrays corresponding to the axes. See numpy.meshgrid. If axes are not constricted by axes argument, the output arrays will have the same shape as the data arrays of the dataset. Uses snomtools.calcs.units.meshgrid() under the hood to preserve units.

Parameters:axes – optional: a list of axes identifiers to be included. If none is given, all axes are included.
Returns:A tuple of coordinate arrays.
project_nd(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Projects the datafield onto the given axes. Uses the DataSet.project_nd() method for every datset and returns a new DataSet with the projected DataFields and the chosen axes.

Parameters:args – Valid identifiers for the axes to project onto.
Returns:DataSet: Projected DataSet.
replace_axis(axis_id, new_axis)[source]¶

Replaces an axis of the dataset with another. For this to make sense, the new axis must describe the same coordinates in the dataset as the old one: Obviously, the shape must therefore be the same.

Parameters:
  • axis_id – Identifier of the Axis to replace. Must be a valid identifier as in get_axis_index and get_axis.
  • new_axis – Axis: An Axis instance that shall be put in place of the old one.
Returns:
replace_datafield(datafield_id, new_datafield)[source]¶

Replaces a datafield of the dataset with another. For this to make sense, the new datafield must describe the same coordinates in the dataset as the old one: Obviously, the shape must therefore be the same.

Parameters:
  • datafield_id – Identifier of the Axis to replace. Must be a valid identifier as in get_datafield_index and get_datafield.
  • new_datafield – Axis: An Axis instance that shall be put in place of the old one.
Returns:

Parameters:h5dest – String or h5py Group/File: The destination to write to.
Returns:Nothing.
set_label(newlabel)[source]¶
classmethod stack(datastack, new_axis, axis=0, label=None, plotconf=None, h5target=None)[source]¶

Stacks a sequence of DataSets to a new DataSet. Therefore it stacks the DataArrays with stack_DataArrays() and inserts a new Axis.

Parameters:
  • datastack – sequence of DataSets: The Data to be stacked.
  • new_axis – Axis or castable as Axis: The new axis to be inserted for the dimension along which the data is stacked.
  • axis – int, optional: The axis in the result array along which the input arrays are stacked.
  • label – string, optional: The label for the new DataSet. If not given, the label of the first DataArray in the input stack is used.
  • plotconf – The plot configuration to be used for the new DataSet. If not given, the configuration of the first DataSet in the input stack is used.
Returns:

The stacked DataSet.

Interchanges the place of two axes.

Parameters:
  • axis1 – The first axis, addressed by its label or index.
  • axis2 – The second axis, addressed by its label or index.
Returns:

Nothing.
class snomtools.data.datasets.Data_Handler_H5[source]¶

Bases: pint.unit.Quantity

A Data Handler, emulating a Quantity. This “H5 mode” handler keeps the data in h5py objects, but provides access to data as if it were a quantity.

__mul__(other)[source]¶
static __new__(data=None, unit=None, shape=None, h5target=None, chunks=True, compression='gzip', compression_opts=4, chunk_cache_mem_size=None)[source]¶

Initializes and returns a new instance. __new__ is used instead of __init__ because pint Quantity does so, and the method is overwritten.

Parameters:
  • data – The data to store.
  • unit – A valid units string for the unit to convert the data to if necessary.
  • shape – If no data is given, data of given shape are initialized with zeroes.
  • h5target (h5py Group/File) – If None or True, temporary file mode is enabled, Data is kept on temp files, which are cleaned up in __del__.
  • chunks – (See h5py docs. Chunks are good in most big data cases!)
  • compression – (See h5py docs. Compression is good in most cases!)
  • compression_opts – (See h5py docs. Compression is good in most cases!)
  • chunk_cache_mem_size – Set custom chunk cache memory size for temp files. Default is set in h5tools.
Returns:

The initialized instance.
__pow__(other)[source]¶
__repr__()[source]¶
__setitem__(key, value)[source]¶

This method provides write access to indexed elements of the data. It directly writes to the h5 dataset without invoking _magnitude, thereby it avoids loading all data into ram.

Parameters:
  • key – Index or slice (numpy style as usual) of data to address.
  • value – Data to write in addressed elements. Input units will be converted to Data_Handler units (error if not possible). Numeric data (non-Quantities) are assumed as dimensionless ( pint-style).

Warning

Value must fit into RAM. Setting bigger-than-RAM slices at a time is not supported (yet).

Returns:Nothing.

flush()[source]¶

Flushes the HDF5 buffer to disk. This always concerns the whole H5 file, so the Data_Handler resides on a subgroup, all other datasets on that file are also flushed. :return: nothing

shape[source]¶
shift(shift, output=None, order=0, mode='constant', cval=nan, prefilter=None, h5target=None)[source]¶

Shifts the complete data with scipy.ndimage.interpolation.shift. In difference to that method, it does not need an input, but works on the instance data. Also, the defaults are different.

Warning

For shifting, the whole data is loaded into RAM. Sequential shifting might be implemented later.

See: scipy.ndimage.interpolation.shift() for full documentation of parameters.

Parameters:
  • output (ndarray or dtype or False, optional) – The array in which to place the output, or the dtype of the returned array. If False is given, the instance data is overwritten.
  • h5target – The h5target to in case a new Data_Handler_H5 is generated.
Returns:

The shifted data. If output is given as a parameter or False, None is returned.
Return type:

Data_Handler_np or None
shift_slice(slice_, shift, output=None, order=0, mode='constant', cval=nan, prefilter=None, h5target=None)[source]¶

Shifts a certain slice of the data with scipy.ndimage.interpolation.shift. See: scipy.ndimage.interpolation.shift() for full documentation of parameters.

Parameters:
  • slice (slice or tuple(slice) or (tuple of) castable.) – A selection of a subset of the data, typically a tuple of ints or slices. Can be generated easily with numpy.s_() or builtin method slice().
  • output (ndarray or dtype or False, optional) – The array in which to place the output, or the dtype of the returned array. If False is given, the slice of the instance data is overwritten.
  • h5target – The h5target to in case a new Data_Handler_H5 is generated.
Returns:

The shifted data. If output is given as a parameter or False, None is returned.
Return type:

Data_Handler_np or None
classmethod stack(tostack, axis=0, unit=None, h5target=None)[source]¶

Stacks a sequence of given Data_Handlers (or castables) along a new axis.

Parameters:
  • tostack – Sequence of Data_Handlers (or castables), each must be of the same shape and unit.
  • axis – int, optional: The axis in the result array along which the input arrays are stacked.
  • unit – optional: A valid unit string to convert the stack to. Default is the unit of the first element of the sequence.
  • h5target – optional: A h5target to work on. See __new__
Returns:

stacked Data_Handler
sum(axis=None, dtype=None, out=None, keepdims=False, h5target=None)[source]¶

Behaves as the sum() function of a numpy array. See: http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.10.1/reference/generated/numpy.sum.html

Parameters:
  • axis – None or int or tuple of ints, optional Axis or axes along which a sum is performed. The default (axis = None) is perform a sum over all the dimensions of the input array. axis may be negative, in which case it counts from the last to the first axis. New in version 1.7.0.: If this is a tuple of ints, a sum is performed on multiple axes, instead of a single axis or all the axes as before.
  • dtype – dtype, optional The type of the returned array and of the accumulator in which the elements are summed. By default, the dtype of a is used. An exception is when a has an integer type with less precision than the default platform integer. In that case, the default platform integer is used instead.
  • out – ndarray, optional Array into which the output is placed. By default, a new array is created. If out is given, it must be of the appropriate shape (the shape of a with axis removed, i.e., numpy.delete(a.shape, axis)). Its type is preserved. See doc.ufuncs (Section Output arguments) for more details.
  • keepdims – bool, optional If this is set to True, the axes which are reduced are left in the result as dimensions with size one. With this option, the result will broadcast correctly against the original arr.
Returns:

ndarray Quantity An array with the same shape as a, with the specified axis removed. If a is a 0-d array, or if axis is None, a scalar is returned. If an output array is specified, a reference to out is returned.
sum_raw(axis=None, dtype=None, out=None, keepdims=False)[source]¶

As sum(), only on bare numpy array instead of Quantity. See sum() for details. :return: ndarray An array with the same shape as a, with the specified axes removed. If a is a 0-d array, or if axis is None, a scalar is returned. If an output array is specified, a reference to out is returned.

class snomtools.data.datasets.Data_Handler_np[source]¶

Bases: pint.unit.Quantity

A Data Handler, emulating a Quantity. This “numpy mode” handler actually just mainly shadows the attributes of the Quantity that is held and should be use as such a Quantity. Of cause this Quantity itself shadows most of the attributes of the underlying numpy array and can therefore be used as one in many contexts.

class snomtools.data.datasets.ROI(dataset, limitlist=None, by_index=False, label='', plotlabel='')[source]¶

Bases: object

A Region of Interest: This is a way to define a (rectangular) mask in the multidimensional DataSet, and then interfacing the generated ROI, as you would the overlying DataSet. Consequently, the ROI shall be implemented to behave as a DataSet.

__dict__ = dict_proxy({'__module__': 'snomtools.data.datasets', 'set_limits': <function set_limits at 0x2b5f445ea230>, 'get_datafield_by_dimension': <function get_datafield_by_dimension at 0x2b5f445ea758>, 'get_axis': <function get_axis at 0x2b5f445ea7d0>, 'meshgrid': <function meshgrid at 0x2b5f445ea938>, 'project_nd': <function project_nd at 0x2b5f445ea9b0>, 'unset_limits': <function unset_limits at 0x2b5f445ea2a8>, '__dict__': <attribute '__dict__' of 'ROI' objects>, '__weakref__': <attribute '__weakref__' of 'ROI' objects>, '__init__': <function __init__ at 0x2b5f445ea0c8>, 'unset_limit_left': <function unset_limit_left at 0x2b5f445ea398>, 'unset_limit_right': <function unset_limit_right at 0x2b5f445ea488>, 'get_datafield_normalized': <function get_datafield_normalized at 0x2b5f445ea6e0>, 'get_datafield': <function get_datafield at 0x2b5f445ea5f0>, '__getattr__': <function __getattr__ at 0x2b5f445ea140>, 'get_limits': <function get_limits at 0x2b5f445ea578>, 'set_limit_left': <function set_limit_left at 0x2b5f445ea320>, 'get_datafield_index': <function get_datafield_index at 0x2b5f445ea668>, 'set_limit_right': <function set_limit_right at 0x2b5f445ea410>, 'get_slice': <function get_slice at 0x2b5f445ea500>, 'get_axis_index': <function get_axis_index at 0x2b5f445ea848>, 'get_axis_by_dimension': <function get_axis_by_dimension at 0x2b5f445ea8c0>, 'set_limits_all': <function set_limits_all at 0x2b5f445ea1b8>, '__doc__': '\n\tA Region of Interest: This is a way to define a (rectangular) mask in the multidimensional DataSet,\n\tand then interfacing the generated ROI, as you would the overlying DataSet.\n\tConsequently, the ROI shall be implemented to behave as a DataSet.\n\t'})¶
__getattr__(item)[source]¶

This method provides dynamical naming in instances. It is called any time an attribute of the intstance is not found with the normal naming mechanism. Raises an AttributeError if the name cannot be resolved.

Parameters:item – The name to get the corresponding attribute.
Returns:The attribute corresponding to the given name.
__init__(dataset, limitlist=None, by_index=False, label='', plotlabel='')[source]¶

The constructor. Translates the given limits to the corresponding array indices and stores them as instance variables. Each set of limits must be given as 2-tuples of the form (start,stop), where start and stop can be a quantity with a value on the axis which will be cast as the next nearest index, a valid axis array index (see by_index), or None for no limitation.

Parameters:
  • dataset – The DataSet instance to work on. A ROI only makes sense on a specific dataset...
  • limitlist – A list or dict containing the limits for each axis. If a dict is given, the keys must be valid identifiers of an axis of the DataSet (see DataSet.get_axis()). If a list is given, each entry must contain the limit set for one axis in the same order as in the axes list of the DataSet, Limit sets must 2-tuples as described above.
  • by_index – Bool flag to interpret limits not as positions, but as array indices.
  • label – String: A label describing the ROI.
  • plotlabel – String: A label describing the ROI for plots.
Returns:
__module__ = 'snomtools.data.datasets'¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

get_datafield_index(label_or_index)[source]¶
get_datafield_normalized(label_or_index, method='maximum')[source]¶

Like get_datafield, but returns a normalized DataArray.

Parameters:
  • label_or_index – Identifier of the DataField
  • method – Method to normalize with: Valid options: * “maximum”, “max” (default): divide every value by the maximum value in the set * “mean”: divide every value by the average value in the set * “minimum”, “min”: divide every value by the minimum value in the set * “absolute maximum”, “absmax”: divide every value by the maximum absolute value in the set * “absolute minimum”, “absmin”: divide every value by the minimum absolute value in the set
Returns:

The normalized DataArray instance.
get_limits(data_key=None, by_index=False, raw=False)[source]¶

Returns the limits that define the ROI. Normally, the physical positions of the limits are given, see by_index. The limits of the axes are given as lists of length 2 (2-lists).

Parameters:
  • data_key – A valid identifier of an axis or datafield of the DataSet (see DataSet.get_axis()) If given, return the limits of an axis of the dataset instead of the whole data array. If the identifier corresponds to a datafield, the whole limit list as with None will be returned.
  • by_index – Boolean flag: If True, return the limit axis indices instead of physical positions on the axis.
  • raw – Boolean flag: If True, return floats instead of quantities.
Returns:

A 2-list or list of 2-lists as specified before.
get_slice(data_key=None)[source]¶

Creates a slice object (or tuple of them) out of the limits of the ROI This can be used directly in the [] for adressing the part of the arrays corresponding to the ROI. See: http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.10.0/reference/generated/numpy.s_.html https://docs.python.org/2/c-api/slice.html

Parameters:data_key – A valid identifier of an axis or datafield of the DataSet (see DataSet.get_axis()) If given, return a slice applicable to an axis of the dataset instead of the whole data array. If the identifier corresponds to a datafield, the whole slice as with None will be returned.
Returns:The create slice object.

Parameters:axes – optional: a list of axes identifiers to be included. If none is given, all axes are included.

Each set of limits must be given as 2-tuples of the form (start,stop), where start and stop can be a quantity with a value on the axis which will be cast as the next nearest index, a valid axis array index (see by_index), or None for an unchanged limit.

snomtools.data.fits module¶

snomtools.data.fits.fit_xy_linear(xdata, ydata)[source]¶

A simple linear fit to data given as x and y values. Fits y = m*x + c and returns c tuple of (m, c), where m and c are quantities according to the physical dimensions of data. Numerical data is assumed as dimensionless.

Parameters:
  • xdata – DataArray or Quantity or numpy array: The x values.
  • ydata – DataArray or Quantity or numpy array: The y values.

:return:tuple: (m, c)

class snomtools.data.fits.gauss_fit(data=None, guess=None, keepdata=True, normalize=False)[source]¶

Bases: object

A Gauss Fit of given data with benefits.

__dict__ = dict_proxy({'__dict__': <attribute '__dict__' of 'gauss_fit' objects>, '__module__': 'snomtools.data.fits', '__weakref__': <attribute '__weakref__' of 'gauss_fit' objects>, '__doc__': '\n\tA Gauss Fit of given data with benefits.\n\t', '__init__': <function __init__ at 0x2b5f492f19b0>})¶

__module__ = 'snomtools.data.fits'¶
__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

snomtools.data.fits.gaussian(x, x_0, sigma, A, C)[source]¶

A Gauss function of the form gaussian(x) = A * exp(-(x-x_0)^2 / 2 sigma^2) + C All parameters can be given as quantities, if so, unit checks are done automatically. If not, correct units are assumed.

Parameters:
  • x – (Same unit as x.) The variable x.
  • x_0 – The center of the gaussian.
  • sigma – (Same unit as x.) The width (standard deviation) of the gaussian. Relates to FWHM by: FWHM = 2 sqrt(2 ln 2) sigma
  • A – (Same unit as C.) The amplitude of the gaussian bell relative to background.
  • C – (Same unit as A.) The constant offset (background) of the curve relative to zero.
Returns:

(Same unit as A and C.) The result of the gaussian function.

snomtools.data.h5tools module¶

snomtools.data.h5tools.File(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Initializes a h5py_cache File object as documented in h5py_cache.File and h5py.File. Uses the value chunk_cache_mem_size_default as defined above as buffer size if not given otherwise explicitly.

Returns:A h5py.File object with the chosen buffer settings.
snomtools.data.h5tools.clear_name(h5dest, name)[source]¶

Removes an entry of a HDF5 group if it exists, thereby clearing the namespace for creating a new dataset.

Parameters:
  • h5dest – The h5py group in which to clear the entry.
  • name – String: The name to clear.
Returns:

nothing
snomtools.data.h5tools.load_dictionary(h5source)[source]¶
snomtools.data.h5tools.store_dictionary(dict_to_store, h5target)[source]¶
snomtools.data.h5tools.write_dataset(h5dest, name, data, **kwargs)[source]¶

Writes a HDF5 dataset to a destination, deleting any data of the same name that are already there first.

Parameters:
  • dest – The HDF5 destination to write to.
  • name – The name of the dataset to be written
  • data – The data to write.
  • kwargs – kwargs to be forwarded to create_dataset.
Returns:

The written dataset.

snomtools.data.tools module¶

snomtools.data.tools.assure_1D(data)[source]¶

Makes sure the data is onedimensional. Try a consistent conversion, if that fails raise error.

Parameters:data – Quantity or numpy array.
Returns:The flattened data or the data itself if it was already 1D.
